utterances: And the clothing that's softer.
But we also had this - I think it was the Washington Post, which is a paper you're familiar with, spent too many column inches on Hillary Clinton's cleavage not too long ago.
Well, I actually - I thought that was great article.
And I'm not just saying that because I work there.

But certainly that, you know - and that sort of played out in the interesting way, because the campaign wound up sending out a note that was attached to a fundraising letter, sort of, using it as way to raise money.
And people were upset about that article.
But, you know, with the Lazio thing it's interesting because I've gone back and talked to people and said, okay, what was your read on that?
Because he brought her this pledge, it was to ban soft money.
And then what…
Hillary, why don't you sign it - well, I don't know if he said Hillary - but why don't you sign it.
And there were who said he would never have done that to a man.
He would never have invaded a man's space that way.
And other people saying, are you crazy?
People do that in debates all the time.
But either way, Lazio loses because even the people who say that it goes on in debates all the time, they recognized that it plays out differently when it's a woman.
There's a sense perhaps of bullying, and there is perhaps an old-fashioned element to our culture where we still expect the guy to be somewhat chivalrous.
Hmm.
Well…
Because if you (unintelligible), so how do you attack?
That was hardly the only problem with Rick Lazio's case.
All right.
Let's see if we get some listeners involved in this conversation.
Serene(ph) joins us.
Serene calling us from Charleston, South Carolina.
Hi.
Thanks for taking my call.
Sure.
Great show.
Thanks.
I'm a lifelong Democrat and I consider myself a feminist, too.
But I think it's a little bit disingenuousness of Hillary's campaigners to use the gender card in this case.
I think she's smart, she's capable, but she's the frontrunner.
And I think that's why the other candidates are trying to distinguish themselves and their platforms and perspectives.
I didn't see it as an attack; I watched that whole debate on MSNBC.
And I, kind of, liken it to when Obama - I think it was the YouTube debate - was sort of attacked by the Hillary campaign and called naive and so forth.
He didn't come back and say it's because he was minority that he was being attacked.
Or that he was young.
Right.
I think Hillary is smart.
I just don't think that this - in this case, that it's a wise move to claim gender was the reason she was…
And Ken, it's interesting, Serene's got a point, of course.
It's not just the Democrats who are attacking her as the frontrunner, it's the Republicans who attack her as the frontrunner.
Well, actually, the way I've been hearing it, it sounds like the Republicans want her to be the frontrunner because, according to what they have to say, they would love to run against her.
And there are not too few Democrats who agree that perhaps they fear that the Republicans would mostly like to run against her.
And even John Edwards have mentioned this at a debate, because they feel she might be the easiest to beat.
All right, Sherene.
Thanks very much for your call.
I appreciate it.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's go to - this is Susan(ph).
Susan's with us from Bakersfield in California.
My comment was that I couldn't imagine - after I heard what Hillary Clinton said the other day, I couldn't imagine having heard Margaret Thatcher or Golda Meir ever saying something like that.
Hmm.
They were in that arena, they were heads of state, and I don't think they ever tried to play that card and I was disappointed that Hillary Clinton played it.
Not to be picky.
They were heads of government, not of state.
But anyway, anybody who's ever been in the room with Margaret Thatcher knows that toughness was not an issue.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Correct.
Right.
I mean, you know, this is what's so interesting.
And this is, as far as I can tell, an argument that is most - being debated most vociferously by women.

It is - women who see her as having been attacked and women who see her as not having been attacked and playing the gender card and who suggest that it's not a feminist thing to do, if you will, or not a strong woman thing to do to kind of pull that out and have that be an issue.
If you noticed how her campaign did it, it was very subtle.
It wasn't direct and she herself was never on record as saying anything along those lines.
She herself said, well, they're attacking me because I'm a frontrunner.
Period.
End of story.

But what was going on and, sort of, some of the coded language, if you will, as some people have seen it that was being sent out by the campaign, that people have interpreted as playing the gender card, so to speak, which has gotten us into this whole big debate about gender.
And I think we're going to be seeing a lot more of this because this is the very beginning of a truly exceptional, truly exceptional campaign with a woman at the front.

Our guest is Libby Copeland, a staff writer with the Washington Post, the author of today's article in the style section, ""Rules for a Fair Fight."" Of course, Ken Rudin is also with us here in Studio 3A.
If you'd like to join us, 800-989-8255, 800-989-TALK.
The e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
You can also weigh in on our blog, that's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
And you're listening to TALK OF THE NATION coming to you from NPR News.
And let's go now to - this is Jennifer(ph).
Jennifer's with us from Minneapolis.
Good afternoon.
I was very disturbed by what I felt with Hillary Clinton playing the gender card.
But, I would say that nothing happens in her campaign without her explicit approval.
She's that kind of - it's come out in several books and articles about her that she's one of those kinds of micromanagers.
And even though she would never say herself that they're all ganging up on her due to her gender, anything that showed up on her Web site.
I mean, nothing, I think, happens in our campaign without her direction.
So…
All right.
It's kind of…
Ken, is that an accurate observation?
Well, there's something to be said about that.
And we always talk about the difference between Bill and Hillary Clinton whenever - as brilliant as Bill Clinton is, was, is, he was not the most organized campaigner in the world.
Whereas Hillary Clinton is so to the letter.
She has her hands on everything and she's really on top of every issue that I've…
Jennifer, thank you.
Thank you.
And let's see if you can go now to Mike(ph).
And Mike's with us from Detroit.
Hi.
Hi.
It seems to me.
I actually feel bad for her because no matter what she does, if she doesn't laugh and acts somewhat normal, she gets criticized for being too severe.
If she laughs, she gets criticized for cackling.
It doesn't seem to matter what she does, she gets criticized for it.
So I wonder why she thinks people are piling on her?
Because she's the frontrunner perhaps, but…
I think you're right.
Libby Copeland, you had something about that last.
This is so, so true.
And this goes back to the issue of is she a woman or is she candidate.
And who can separate the two, right?
I mean, remember the flap about her laugh.
The ha, ha, ha, right, that she was doing and how that was sort of pored over.
And, you know, when I was in a conversation with Pat Schroeder the other day, she said, you know, how come people don't comment on the president's laugh?
He sounds like Woody Woodpecker and then she demonstrated he, he, he.
People have made fun of his laugh.
Perhaps, I don't know that it's been perhaps as scrutinized on talk shows as her laugh was, but it's certainly been made fun of.
But the point is that, you know, everything takes on a completely different cast when you're talking about, you know, Hillary Clinton and gender in it, everything has this extra level to it.
You know what, I'm just struck by is that the women who've just called in to talk about - to comment on this, were all critical of Hillary Clinton playing the gender card.
And we just heard from Mike, the first male we've heard from, who said, look, give Hillary a break.
I think that was interesting.
Mm-hmm.
Mm-hmm.
Mike, thanks very much for the call.
